text:
On Friday, our campaign train arrived at Igbo-Ukwu and Ekwulobia in Aguata Local Government Area, where I was warmly received by a massive crowd of supporters, traditional rulers, and community leaders who share in our collective vision for a new and better Anambra State.

I am deeply grateful to the people of Aguata for their unwavering faith in our Recovery Agenda, which seeks to rebuild our dear state on the solid foundations of integrity, equity, and people-centered leadership. Together, we will restore dignity in governance and return power to the people through accountability, transparency, and genuine service.

As I shared with our people, our Recovery Agenda will ensure free and compulsory education from primary to secondary school, revive the State Scholarship Board, and make massive investments in agriculture to create jobs, reduce poverty, and boost food production. We will also provide free medical care for citizens aged 65 and above and a monthly welfare allowance for those from 70 years, because a compassionate society must care for its elderly and vulnerable.

Our government will also reform the revenue collection system, end multiple taxation, and empower ndi Aka ·ªåd·ªç, traders, transporters, and artisans to thrive without harassment or exploitation.

To the wonderful people of Igbo-Ukwu and Ekwulobia, I say thank you. Your love, trust, and encouragement strengthen my resolve to serve with integrity, compassion, and an unshakable commitment to the Recovery of Anambra State.

profile_bio.description:

üíº‚ÄØPublic Servant | Visionary Leader | Advocate for Good Governance

text:
Umunnem Ndi Anambra,

As we joyfully step into the month of November, a month that carries the destiny of our beloved state, I greet you with a heart full of gratitude to God, hope for a new beginning, and deep confidence in our collective strength to rebuild Anambra. Over the past months, I have visited nearly every community in our dear state. I have walked through our streets, markets, and villages. I have spoken with our traders, okada riders, keke and bus drivers, farmers, women, and youths. I have listened to your cries, your fears, and your dreams. I have felt your pain over multiple taxation, harassment by Ndi Aka ·ªåd·ªç, insecurity, bad roads, and the absence of functional hospitals and quality schools. These are not just stories to me; they are the reality of our people, and they have touched my heart deeply, strengthening my resolve to make things right.

Let me assure you from the depth of my heart that within one month of my swearing-in, the activities of Ndi Aka ·ªåd·ªç who are being used to exploit our people in the name of revenue collection will stop. Under a Labour Party government, no one will be harassed or punished for striving to earn an honest living. We will build a transparent and humane system that supports business growth, uplifts traders and artisans, and rewards hard work.

I believe that power comes from God, and He alone gives it to whom He chooses. If God grants me the privilege to serve as your governor, I will bring to bear my experience, competence, and proven record of service to build an Anambra that works for everyone, an Anambra where justice will be our foundation, peace our guide, and prosperity our shared reward.

My covenant with you, Ndi Anambra, is from the heart. Education will be free and compulsory from primary to secondary school. We will reintroduce the State Scholarship Board to support our brilliant and hardworking children. Free medical care will be provided for our elderly from 65 years and above, and those who are 70 and above will receive a monthly allowance as a token of love and appreciation for their sacrifices. We will fix our roads, strengthen healthcare, create jobs, secure our communities, and reinvest in agriculture to provide food, employment, and economic growth for our people.

This November 8th, destiny calls. It is a call for renewal, for unity, and for a return to leadership that listens, cares, and serves. Let us rise together as one family, bound by truth, fairness, and the desire to make Anambra great again. Together, we will take back our state and rebuild it with love, honesty, and dedication. Vote Labour Party. Support Dr. George Moghalu. Anambra ga adi mma ·ªçz·ªç.

text:
CELEBRATING MY ROYAL FATHER, HIS ROYAL HIGHNESS IGWE KENNETH ORIZU III, AT 100

Today, I joyfully join the good people of Nnewi and countless well-wishers across the world to celebrate our beloved monarch, His Royal Highness, Igwe Kenneth Onyeneke Orizu III, on his 100th birthday anniversary.

Igwe Orizu is not just our traditional ruler; he is a father, a mentor, and a source of inspiration. His century-long reign has been defined by peace, wisdom, and purposeful leadership. Truly, his life is a rare testimony of God‚Äôs grace and a blessing to Nnewi and to Nigeria at large.

I thank God for keeping him strong and healthy. At 100, His Majesty still walks with strength, works with passion, and reads without glasses. What a blessing from God. His wise counsel has guided many of us who have had the privilege of serving under him, myself included. Under his reign, Nnewi has continued to enjoy peace, unity, and progress.

As we celebrate this remarkable milestone, I pray that God will continue to bless His Royal Highness with good health, renewed strength, and divine grace. May his reign continue to bring wisdom, harmony, and blessings to our great town.

Long Live His Royal Highness, Igwe K.O.N. Orizu III!
Long Live the Nnewi Kingdom!!

üíº‚ÄØPublic Servant | Visionary Leader | Advocate for Good Governance

text:
Earlier this week, I met with our hardworking traders, transport operators, and market leaders at the All Saints Cathedral Hall, Onitsha, where we discussed the urgent need to rescue Anambra‚Äôs economy from collapse. I told them clearly that our state has reached a critical point that requires honest, transparent, and visionary leadership. Our traders have endured so much under an unbearable tax regime, insecurity, and years of government neglect. Yet, their resilience continues to sustain the heart of our economy. I assured them that under my watch, dignity and prosperity will return to commerce in our dear state.

Many traders spoke with deep frustration about the multiple levies, daily extortions, and illegal collections by agberos. They narrated how Keke and Okada riders, as well as bus drivers, are forced to pay tolls every day just to survive. Some lamented that even when they park their Keke without working, they are still compelled to pay. They described this system as wicked and oppressive, explaining that no market has been rebuilt or modernized while small businesses continue to collapse under the weight of exploitation.

In response, I made it clear that this injustice must end. I vowed that once elected, my administration will abolish the notorious Aka ·ªåd·ªç system, stop the harassment of traders and transporters, and establish a fair and transparent revenue structure that prioritizes people over profit. I also pledged to end the imposition of market leaders and allow traders to freely choose and elect their representatives without government interference. I told them plainly: ‚ÄúIf Soludo returns, he will not come with Aka ·ªåd·ªç again ‚Äî this time, he will come with a hammer.‚Äù

I reminded them that good leadership is about service and vision. Look at Governor Alex Otti of Abia State‚Äîwithin two years, he has transformed Ariaria International Market, rebuilt critical infrastructure, and restored confidence among traders. That is what purposeful leadership can do when there is sincerity and commitment to the people. In my time as Managing Director of the National Inland Waterways Authority (NIWA), I also delivered results‚Äîunder my watch, the first commercial barge entered the Onitsha River Port 42 years after its construction, and we built the Odekpe Jetty in Ogbaru Local Government Area. I also led the successful concession of the Onitsha River Port to Universal Elysium Limited, in partnership with China National Electrical Engineering Limited, Port of Antwerp, and China Harbor Engineering Company (Nigeria) Ltd‚Äîprojects aimed at positioning Onitsha as a major trade hub in the Southeast.

text:
Yesterday, in continuation of our community-to-community campaign tour, I visited Oraukwu community in Idemili North Local Government Area. We were warmly received by enthusiastic supporters, community leaders, and traditional rulers whose faith in a better Anambra strengthens our resolve.

Accompanied by my running mate, Hon. Mrs. Ifeoma Okaro, we first paid homage to His Royal Highness, Igwe Emeka Onuorah, the traditional ruler of Oraukwu Kingdom. His royal blessings, words of wisdom, and prayers for divine guidance reaffirmed our shared vision to lead with humility, sincerity, and the fear of God.

Addressing the gathering, I reiterated my commitment to govern Anambra State with the fear of God, guided by fairness, compassion, and accountability. I pledged to end the excessive taxation on traders, describing the current system as harsh and unfriendly to business growth. We also announced plans to provide free medical care for the elderly and introduce a monthly welfare allowance for citizens aged 70 years and above, ensuring that our senior citizens live in comfort and dignity. In addition, we pledged to expand scholarship opportunities for brilliant but less privileged students across the state, because every child deserves the chance to succeed.

Our visit to Oraukwu was not just another campaign stop ‚Äî it was a reaffirmation of our commitment to inclusive governance, to listen to the people, and to build an Anambra where every citizen feels seen, valued, and supported. With faith in God and the collective will of our people, a new Anambra is possible.

I have always believed that Ayamelum holds the key to reviving our state‚Äôs agricultural strength, and my visit once again reaffirmed that conviction.

I reminded our people that despite Ayamelum‚Äôs vast fertile lands and the blessings of the Omambala River, the area has suffered years of neglect due to poor roads, flooding, and lack of agricultural infrastructure. If entrusted with the mandate to serve, my administration will implement a comprehensive Agricultural and Rural Renewal Plan to reconstruct rural roads, provide irrigation systems, control flooding, and establish agro-processing and storage centers that will empower farmers, create jobs, and restore Ayamelum‚Äôs place as the food powerhouse of Anambra.

While I commend the efforts of the present administration, I must say that their best is not enough because you cannot give what you do not have. For instance, the General Hospital in Anaku, originally built by former Governor Peter Obi, was recently repainted and renamed Solution General Hospital. They claimed to have conducted several surgeries and recruited new staff, but credible reports from residents show that nothing of such actually took place. Our people deserve genuine service, not propaganda and repainting projects.

As part of my commitment to human welfare, I announced plans to provide free medical care for the elderly from 65 years and above, and a monthly allowance for citizens aged 70 years and above. I also reaffirmed my resolve to ensure free and compulsory education for every child in Anambra. My mission remains clear: to build a compassionate government that prioritizes people over politics, restores dignity to the aged, empowers our farmers, and ensures that Anambra truly works for all.

text:
Yesterday, I had the privilege of worshipping with the Methodist Church Nigeria, Diocese of Awka, at the Cathedral of the Holy Trinity, Amaenyi, under the leadership of Rt. Rev. Dr. M. O. Nwakama. It was a fulfilling moment of fellowship with the clergy and laity, and an opportunity to share thoughts on the collective task of rebuilding our beloved Anambra State.

I reminded the congregation that our state, once a pride of education, enterprise, and excellence, has sadly drifted into decline. No investor will bring resources into an unsafe environment. Our educational system has collapsed, agriculture has been abandoned, and this government has not invested a single naira in that vital sector. Anambra deserves better, and our people deserve leadership that truly serves.

I also commended my brother, Dr. Alex Otti, for the bold reforms he has carried out in Abia State within just two years. His achievements in infrastructure, fiscal management, and public confidence show what true vision and integrity can achieve. That is the kind of leadership our people need‚Äîfocused, sincere, and result-oriented, not one driven by empty rhetoric.

Above all, I reaffirmed my belief that power belongs to God, who gives it to whomever He wills. I humbly seek your prayers, your faith, and your partnership. Pray for me, speak for me, and defend me. Together, with God on our side, we will build a new Anambra founded on justice, productivity, and hope. Our state has all it takes to prosper; what remains is the right leadership to unlock its greatness.

profile_bio.description: Former Governor, Anambra State. LP Presidential Candidate, 2023. Tweets by him are signed -PO.

text:
My attention was drawn to reports that Anambra East donated ‚Ç¶50 million to the incumbent government, while erosion is fast cutting off the only road leading to the largest market in that same area.

If this is true, then we, as leaders, must pause and search our conscience. Something is fundamentally wrong when a community battling for survival is compelled to donate millions instead of receiving help.

It pains me deeply that several of our hardworking communities continue to give so much despite being neglected for years. During our community-to-community visits, I witnessed the painful reality: in Ihiala, people have endured over ten years without electricity, yet they still contributed; in Nawgu, the community primary school has no fence and no safe environment for learning; in Ogbaru, the only access road remains the one built long ago by His Excellency, Mr. Peter Obi; in Ayamelum and Achalla, the story is one of abandonment; and even Ogidi, which was almost wiped out by flood, still found a way to donate millions.

My heart bleeds for our people. I ask again ‚Äî are we cursed, or are we simply the architects of our own pain?

text:
Our community-to-community campaign continued yesterday with a highly inspiring outing across Ukpo, Nawgu, Ukwulu, Nkwelle Ezunaka, Umunya, and Ogbunike. It was another opportunity to meet our people, listen to their concerns, and share our message of hope, competence, and compassion for a better Anambra.

I was deeply honoured to have our leader and former Governor of Anambra State, His Excellency Mr. Peter obi, lead the campaign train. His words of encouragement and endorsement remain a great source of strength to me and my running mate, Hon. Mrs. Ifeoma Okaro. Speaking at Ogbunike, Mr. Obi described the town as a place of reference and reminded us all that true leadership must have a human face anchored on compassion and capacity. He urged Ndi Anambra never to sell their votes, emphasizing that our administration will make education the bedrock of development.

We also paid courtesy visits to our revered traditional rulers, whose prayers and counsel continue to inspire us. Those we visited include His Royal Majesty, Igwe Sir. George E. Okaa Onwuogu (KSM); HRM Igwe Ezeike of Ukwulu Kingdom; HRM Igwe Sir Obiora Anachuna; Igwe Orazulunye Nkwelle Ezunaka; and HRH Igwe (Dr.) Robert Eze, Okofia VI of Ukpo. Their words of wisdom and royal blessings strengthened our commitment to serve with humility and integrity.

Everywhere we went, our people expressed deep frustration over the poor state of education, medical care, and infrastructure. I assured them that our administration will change this story by making education free and compulsory, reviving the State Scholarship Board, ending excessive taxation, tackling insecurity, and abolishing the menace of Ndi Aka ·ªåd·ªç. We will also provide free healthcare for citizens from 65 years and above, and a monthly allowance for those above 70. Most importantly, we will build durable roads that stand the test of time not the type that wash away after one rainy season.

Our Deputy Governorship Candidate, Hon. Mrs. Ifeoma Okaro, received a heroic welcome in her hometown of Ogbunike, where she urged our people to stand firm with the Labour Party and vote for a people-oriented and transparent government. Together with the support of leaders like Hon. Uche Okafor (Wiper), we are building a united movement of hope and service.

The journey continues. Our mission is clear‚Äîto restore Anambra to the path of good governance, equity, and development.

text:
On Sunday, I was hosted by the Anambra State Town Union Association, Aba Branch, at the Aba Sports Club. It was a truly emotional homecoming for me because Aba is where I was born and raised. The love and support I received from Ndi Anambra living in the city strengthened my commitment to build a better, fairer, and more prosperous Anambra.

I shared my vision for a new Anambra anchored on education, security, infrastructure, and transparency. Under my leadership, education will be free and compulsory because it remains the most powerful weapon for change. Every child, rich or poor, deserves the opportunity to learn and succeed.

While I commend Governor Soludo for his efforts, the truth remains that his best is not working. Anambra deserves better leadership that delivers real results, not excuses.

I also spoke against the shameful Aka Odo extortion that punishes our traders and transporters. It will stop within one hour of my swearing in. Governance should bring relief, not suffering.

Security will be a top priority of my administration. We must make Anambra safe again, restore public confidence, and build a system that truly works for the people.

I remain a strong believer in equity and zoning. I am a beneficiary of zoning, and I will uphold it. Four years is enough for any serious minded leader to make a difference. Look at what Governor Alex Otti has achieved in Abia within just two years; that is the kind of focused leadership I will bring to Anambra.

Together, we will change the story of our beloved state and make Anambra a true model of good governance.

text:
Today, I join millions of the faithful across Anambra State and beyond to celebrate a great servant of God, a mentor, and a father figure, His Grace, Most Rev. Valerian Maduka Okeke, the Archbishop of Onitsha, on the joyous occasion of his 72nd birthday anniversary. Your Grace has remained a guiding light to our generation, an epitome of humility, wisdom, and devotion whose words and deeds continue to inspire faith, compassion, and service to humanity.

Through your visionary leadership and the Archbishop Valerian Okeke Foundation (AVOF), you have continued to transform lives and raise young ambassadors of goodwill who have represented our state and nation in countries such as Ghana. Your passion for youth empowerment, moral reawakening, and educational advancement has built bridges of opportunity and strengthened the foundation of character formation in our society.

I recall with deep admiration your historic role in the revival of mission schools in Anambra State. Your persistent advocacy led to their return to the Church during the administration of Governor Peter Obi, after which you spearheaded an era of massive reconstruction and reform. Under your watch, mission schools experienced unprecedented transformation through teacher and priest training, science competitions, reintroduction of priests as principals, and renewed emphasis on moral and religious education, initiatives that restored excellence and brought our schools to national and international recognition.

As you mark this remarkable milestone, I thank God for your life of unwavering service and spiritual leadership. I remain personally grateful for your friendship, wise counsel, and moral guidance, which continue to inspire me and many others. May the Almighty bless you with sound health, divine wisdom, and many more fruitful years in His vineyard. Happy 72nd Birthday, Your Grace, Most Rev. Valerian Maduka Okeke.

text:
HEAVEN HAS GAINED A SOLDIER OF FAITH
With deep sorrow, I received the news of the passing of Rev. Dr. Uma Ukpai, a true servant of God and one of the greatest evangelists of our time. His death is a monumental loss to the body of Christ and to humanity.

Rev. Ukpai lived a life wholly devoted to God‚Äôs work. He preached the gospel with power, humility, and faith, touching countless lives through his ministry. He was a father figure, a moral voice, and a source of inspiration to many of us who were privileged to encounter his calling.

profile_bio.description:

text:
Yesterday, as we visited Ihiala and Uli in continuation of our community-to-community campaign tour, I was deeply pained by the cries of our people who lamented that they have not had electricity for the past ten years. Ihiala is my maternal home, and hearing such complaints from my own people touched me deeply. It is heartbreaking and unacceptable that in this modern age, entire communities have been left in total darkness for a decade.

I recall that on March 24th, 2023, the current administration announced that it had signed a Memorandum of Understanding (MoU) with the Enugu Electricity Distribution Company (EEDC) to ensure 24-hour power supply across the state. Sadly, what we witnessed in Ihiala and Uli tells a completely different story. The people have neither seen electricity nor felt any improvement since that announcement.

It is distressing that such neglect exists under a government that claims to prioritize development. I heard their cries and I assured them that under my leadership, such situations will not persist. We will not just make promises or sign MoUs for publicity; we will deliver reliable electricity to every community in Anambra, because power is essential to economic growth, education, and human dignity.

Ihiala, Uli, and every part of our dear state deserve light ‚Äî and by God‚Äôs grace, we will make it happen.

I made it clear that within one hour of my swearing-in, the illegal ‚ÄúAka Odo‚Äù revenue collectors will be disbanded and all exploitative levies abolished to build a fair and business-friendly Anambra.

text:
OUR PLAN TO END INSECURITY IN ANAMBRA STATE

One of the greatest challenges confronting Anambra State today is insecurity. Our once peaceful and vibrant homeland has become a place where fear walks freely, where citizens can no longer move safely from one community to another, and where traders close their shops before nightfall.

But let me assure you, addressing insecurity is not rocket science. It has been successfully done elsewhere, and it can be done here in Anambra. All it requires is political will, sincere leadership, and a well-structured plan. By the grace of God, when we form government, our approach to security will be strategic, technology-driven, and people-oriented.

1. Building a Modern Command and Control System

We will establish a Command and Control Centre that will serve as the nerve of our security operations. Through this center, we will monitor all activities across the state in real time using advanced CCTV cameras strategically installed in markets, highways, and public spaces. This digital monitoring system will enable us to track criminal movements, respond swiftly to emergencies, and ensure that no part of Anambra is left unprotected.

2. Community-Based Security Network

Anambra has 179 communities, and under our administration, every community will have a brand-new pickup vehicle for security operations ‚Äî not second-hand tokunbo buses or sienna cars, but durable, purpose-built patrol vehicles. Each vehicle will be equipped with a modern radio communication system linking all communities together and connecting them to Local government and state police command stations. If any security issue arises in one community, others can be immediately alerted, allowing for coordinated and rapid response. That is how to secure our people through community cooperation, real-time communication, and proactive intelligence.

3. Professionalizing the Vigilante System

Our local vigilantes are vital to community safety, but they have been neglected, underpaid, and misused. We will change that. Under my administration, every vigilante member will be properly documented, trained, and well-paid. We will bring in retired military and police officers from our state to train them in discipline, intelligence gathering, and crisis management. We will make community security a dignified and respectable service, not a gathering of touts and untrained individuals.

The era of our vigilantes being paid peanuts is over. They will earn good salaries that will attract even graduates to join. We will restore professionalism, respect, and accountability in our security structure.

4. Welfare and Insurance for Security Personnel

We will introduce a comprehensive insurance and welfare package for every security officer serving in Anambra State, whether from the police, military, or vigilante service. This package will cover the education of their children, their healthcare, and accommodation. In the unfortunate event of death, their families will not be abandoned.

When security officers know their families are cared for, they will give their all in service. They will see Anambra as a state where their efforts are valued and their welfare is protected.

5. A Safe and Prosperous Anambra for All

Our vision is simple ‚Äî to make Anambra the safest state in Nigeria. A state where businesses thrive, where our youths can move freely, and where our mothers and daughters can sleep without fear. Under our leadership, we will combine technology, intelligence, community partnership, and human welfare to build a strong, united, and secure Anambra.

Because true governance begins with security, and security begins with leadership that truly cares.

Labour Party Governorship Candidate in Anambra State, Dr. George Moghalu, has criticised Governor Chukwuma Soludo for turning the 2025 Teachers‚Äô Day celebration into a political exercise rather than an opportunity to address the challenges facing educators across the state.

In a statement made available by his Special Assistant on Media, Johnson Okoye, Dr. Moghalu described as unfortunate the directive compelling teachers and school proprietors to participate in a rally organised under the guise of celebrating teachers. He condemned the alleged instruction to school principals to submit the photocopy of teachers‚Äô voter‚Äôs cards, including their polling unit details and phone numbers, ahead of the event, describing it as ‚Äúa blatant act of political intimidation and abuse of authority.‚Äù

Dr. Moghalu said that Teachers‚Äô Day is globally recognised as a time to celebrate the invaluable role of teachers and reflect on their welfare, not a platform for partisan mobilisation. He urged Governor Soludo to channel his energy toward addressing the real issues confronting teachers, including poor remuneration, lack of teaching materials, delayed promotions, and inadequate infrastructure. ‚ÄúBefore organising rallies in their name, the governor should first address their welfare package and conditions of service,‚Äù he stated.

Reaffirming his commitment to quality education, Dr. Moghalu assured that under a Labour Party-led government, education would be treated as the foundation of development. He promised improved welfare for teachers, investment in modern learning facilities, and the restoration of dignity to the teaching profession. ‚ÄúTeachers are not political instruments; they are nation builders who deserve respect, motivation, and sincere leadership,‚Äù he concluded.

Moghalu said: ‚ÄúIn 2003 when I first ran for Governor under the platform of ANPP, the Governor Soludo did support me and even donated generously to my campaign ‚Äì this shows he believes not just in my ability to govern but also in my capacity to win the election. With its fertile lands and dedicated farmers, Ayamelum truly holds the key to Anambra‚Äôs agricultural revolution.

My administration will prioritize mechanized farming, irrigation systems, accessible farm roads, and agro-processing industries to unlock the full agricultural potential of this region. These initiatives will not only boost food production but also create jobs and sustainable wealth for our people.

Our Recovery Agenda remains people focused with free and compulsory education for our children, free healthcare for our elderly, and monthly stipends for citizens aged 70 and above. Leadership to me is not about power but about compassion, service, and the genuine desire to uplift lives.

text:
INDEPENDENCE AT 65:ANAMBRA AT CROSSROADS, TIME TO RECLAIM HER GREATNESS

My beloved Ndi Anambra, my fellow Nigerians, today we join our compatriots across the nation and beyond to celebrate 65 years of Nigeria‚Äôs independence. October 1st is not just a date in history; it is a reminder of the sacrifices of our founding fathers and mothers who secured for us the dignity of self-rule, the pride of nationhood, and the hope of a prosperous future.

Independence Day is a time for celebration, but it is also a moment for sober reflection. We must ask: have we, as a state and as a people, lived up to the promise of independence? In Anambra, the truth is sobering. Our state, known for excellence, resilience, and industry, has sadly been reduced to a shadow of its great potential. 

According to the Phillips Consulting Limited (PCL) States Performance Index 2025, Anambra is ranked 36th overall, placing us in the red zone of livability in Nigeria. This should deeply trouble us all. In road quality, our state is ranked 31st, exposing the poor standard of roads being constructed. In capital expenditure per capita, we are ranked 33rd, showing limited reinvestment into the very infrastructure that drives development. In public healthcare quality, Anambra is ranked 30th, highlighting the collapse of our hospitals and the struggles of our people to access decent healthcare. In education, we are ranked 34th, a painful reminder of how far our schools have declined and how little attention is given to the future of our children.

Insecurity has worsened. Anambra State have recorded over 300 deaths since inception of this current administration.  Revenue collection has been handed over to Aka-odo touts who exploit our traders and entrepreneurs. To make matters worse, our local governments, which should be the engine of grassroots development, have been crippled. Between January and June this year, Anambra‚Äôs local governments received over ‚Ç¶60.2 billion from Federation Account Allocation Committee (FAAC). Yet, the state government hijacks these funds, leaving LGAs with barely 10 percent, only enough to pay salaries, with no meaningful impact in our communities.

My dear people, this is not governance. This is not service. And this is not the Anambra that our heroes, past and present, fought to build. But I come before you today, not only to lament, but to offer hope. For every challenge we face, there is a solution. For every setback, there is a chance to rebuild. For every pain, there is a promise of healing.

That is why I, Dr. George Moghalu, have offered myself to serve you as Governor under the Labour Party, a party of the people and for the people. Together, we can build durable roads and infrastructure that stand the test of time; revive and modernize our education system to prepare our children for the future; restore dignity to healthcare so that no Anambra son or daughter is left behind in sickness; secure our communities, ensuring that traders, farmers, and businesses thrive without fear; and empower local governments to work for the people, ensuring that allocations are used for real development and not political patronage.

My vision is simple but profound: to return government to the people, to serve with integrity, to govern with accountability, and to build an Anambra that truly reflects the greatness of her people. Fellow Ndi Anambra, independence reminds us that freedom is never given, it is won. Progress is never wished for, it is worked for. Together, we can reclaim our state from the grip of underperformance and usher in a new dawn of prosperity, dignity, and hope.

As we raise our green white green flag today, let it remind us that the promise of Nigeria and the dream of Anambra are still alive. With faith, unity, and courage, we shall build the Anambra of our dreams.

Happy Independence Day!
God bless Anambra State!!
God bless the Federal Republic of Nigeria!!!

Dr. George Moghalu
Labour Party Governorship Candidate

text:
On Urban Regeneration

I will invest substantially in our major cities, particularly Onitsha, Nnewi, and Awka.

Take Onitsha for instance: my government will embark on waterfront development to boost tourism, improve the aesthetics of the city, and, above all, bring back nightlife. We will carry out massive rehabilitation of internal roads across major streets, expand those that can be expanded, plant trees, and install streetlights.

Within four years, my government will build a 25MW power plant in Onitsha to power industries in the city and beyond. We will also build a modern bus and logistics terminal to enhance the transportation of goods and services across the state.

The long-abandoned Onitsha Library will be rebuilt and equipped within my first 100 days in office. Business training institutions like Onitsha Business School will not only receive government support, but more such institutions will be encouraged and established.

The Onitsha Sports Club land currently under litigation will be returned to the club, while the Chuba Ikpeazu Stadium will be remodeled through a Public-Private Partnership. Our markets will open on Mondays again, and touting will be dealt with decisively.

Together, we can build sustainable, vibrant cities across Anambra‚Äîstarting with Onitsha.

quoted_tweet.text:
@MoghaluGeorge Pls where can I download and/or study your manifesto? And is it possible to get answers to the following questions:

1. Given the reigns of leadership of Anambra, do you see a pathway to transform Anambra state to a thriving, vibrant and civilised society? How long do you think such a transformation will take and under that conditions of nationhood?

2. What are the critical factors holding a state like Anambra back, despite having one of Nigeria‚Äôs foremost markets in Onitsha? How do you intend to leverage this commercial opportunity to create a modern, high technology economy?

3. What particular skill sets do you think Anambra citizens possess which your government can build around and present as a major global leader?

4. What is your policy on research and development, particularly at doctoral and postdoctoral level? Do you see a connection between a thriving research community at that level and industrialisation and innovation on high end technologies? Will your government have any clear cut approach towards making Anambra a hub for cutting edge innovation and business development, bridging the gap between industry and academia? 
If yes, who do you have to champion such a policy? How do you intend to fund such a program? To what end? What will be the focus of such a program? 

5. There‚Äôs a growing consciousness of the need to shift from traditional education to a more skill based, technical and technological approach. What will be your administration‚Äôs approach to building one of Nigeria‚Äôs most impactful and rreault oriented effective educational structure in Anambra?

6. Government and governance has a lot to do with social engineering and reorientation of human behavior. Governments must rise to the occasion of reeducating and reorienting their citizens and residents towards more civilised, first world behaviour. What programmes do you see your government undertaking to effectively create a society in Anambra that will be known for calm, conducive, safe and stable lifestyle? 

7. How will you effectively implement tax and levy reforms and move away from the primitive approach this current administration is employing? 

8. If Anambra state decides to give you the mandate, can you paint us a picture of what Awka will look like, infrastructurally, socially, economically, in 4 years and, potentially in 8 years under your leadership?

9. What will be your recruitment approach to critical positions such as Commisoners for Power, Education, Health, Finance, Business and Trade? Will you simply appoint political allies, or will you scour the globe for the brightest and most pragmatic candidates, subject them to gruesome interviews, and select the best on merit, irrespective of political affiliation or residency?

10. Have you conquered greed, the desire for primitive and primordial accumulation of wealth, the unquenchable craving for power? Are you the sort of man who will roll up his sleeve, knock off the umbrella, stand under the rain and lead the charge for dynamic leadership in the 21st century, or are you just another Nigerian politician hoping to waste another 4/8 years of Anambra destiny?

profile_bio.description: Former Governor, Anambra State. LP Presidential Candidate, 2023. Tweets by him are signed -PO.

text: Yesterday at St. Andrews Cathedral Methodist Church, Awada, I humbled myself before God and His people, seeking prayers and partnership for the journey to rebuild our beloved state. I spoke from the heart about the painful realities confronting us‚Äîrising insecurity, collapsed agriculture, and failing education, even as WAEC is about to start  computer-based exams while Anambra still lacks functional e-schools. My vision is clear: to lead a people-centered government where every child can dream, every trader can work without fear, every farmer can return to the land, and every family can feel safe and secure. I was strengthened as Rt. Rev. E. C. Nnaji, Rt. Rev. M. O. Nwakama, and His Grace, Most Rev. Dr. V. C. Onoh prayed for me, declaring that the will of God be done in Anambra. With faith, courage, and the support of the people, I believe our tomorrow will be brighter, and together, we will make Anambra a land of hope and opportunity again.

text:
Yesterday was a very emotional day for me, as my team and I spent the whole day engaging with our people in the most important city in the South East ‚Äî Onitsha.

I had the honour of visiting the Onitsha Business School, owned by Professor Olusegun Oludapo Sogbesan, where I interacted with young businessmen and women. I shared with them the vision I had when I concessioned the Onitsha River Port as the MD of NIWA, because I understood the importance of the port to the growth of the city and the Anambra State economy in general. 

I also answered questions on what I would do differently when I eventually get to the Lighthouse, which includes ‚Äî but is not limited to ‚Äî access to capital, power, infrastructure, and the high cost of capital. All these will be addressed by my government to ensure that we retain our best brains here.

Let me assure young entrepreneurs in Anambra that, as Governor, I will hold frequent Town Halls with them to listen to their needs and tailor my administration‚Äôs programmes accordingly. I do not know everything, and as such, I will not be an ‚ÄúEze Onye Agwanam.‚Äù

Biko, umunnem, come and join me ‚Äî let‚Äôs #RecoverAnambra together.

text:
I met and exchanged pleasantries with my very respected elder brother and the Outgoing Governor of Anambra State Prof Charles Soludo

Like I have consistently said in the past, it will be unfair to say that Prof Soludo has not done anything in the state since he took oat of office but his best is clearly not good enough. 

The majority of the roads he awarded are either poorly constructed, failing or abandoned entirely;  The quality of education in our state has dropped drastically as reported by all the examination bodies. I want to bring seriousness into governance and change the narrative in our dear state same way I approached past public offices I have held in the past with so much seriousness

On Monday 15th September, my team and I took the #RecoveryAgenda message to market leaders in Lagos 

We had very honest conversations about the ease of doing business in our state Anambra; from double taxation to poor market infrastructure to touting etc...

One of the key components of my #RecoveryAgenda is to bring back our trading glory as Ndi Anambra but to attract our top businessmen back to the State, we must upgrade our markets to meet the standards obtainable in top cities across the world 

As the DG of NIWA, I worked hard to operationalize Onitsha River Port bearing in mind that Anambra cannot realise her potentials without the presence of a functional port in the state. 

As the Governor of Anambra, be rest assured that I will prioritise Businessmen and ensure that Anambra State becomes the best place to do business in West Africa 

I have not failed in any public office I have held in the past and I will not fail Ndi Anambra as your Governor 

I urge you to join me let's #RecoverAnambra umunnem

text:
NOV POLL: BE CIVIL, SHUN CAMPAIGN OF CALUMNY ‚Äì MOGHALU TELLS CANDIDATES

Labour Party Governorship Candidate in Anambra state, Dr George Moghalu has described as embarrassing ongoing campaign of calumny among major candidates of political parties in the state ahead of November 8 election.

He regretted that rather than engage in issue based campaign, including offering solutions to prevailing insecurity in the state, politicians preferred toeing the path of incivility and casting aspersions on others.

Addressing newsmen on Wednesday, Moghalu said such mundane issues of certificate and infidelity were too infantile to constitute distractions to weightier issues bedeviling the state.

He said, ‚ÄúIt‚Äôs quite embarrassing what we politicians engage in. We shouldn‚Äôt belittle ourselves getting involved in mundane and personal issues and casting aspersions with foul language.

‚ÄúI believe campaign should be conducted in an orderly and civil manner. There are more contending issues in our polity to talk about. Talking about sex issues and certificates is lowering the bar.

‚ÄúWe should concentrate on what we‚Äôre going to offer the people especially as November 8 election approaches.

‚ÄúIf we see things not working well in government, it behoves on us to draw the attention of the citizenry to those shortcomings and profer solutions.

‚ÄúWhat should engage us is to market ourselves and how we intend to alleviate their burden and contribute in making the state better by changing the narratives.

‚ÄúWe must concentrate on delivering our promises, seeking their consent and entering into contracts and agreement with the electorate.

‚ÄúThe government in power hasn‚Äôt done enough as far as I‚Äôm concerned. That‚Äôs why we‚Äôre in the race to offer alternatives.

‚ÄúFor example, during the time of Peter Obi, Anambra has never missed first or second position in education. Same Obi distributed buses and computers to schools.

‚ÄúBut currently, we‚Äôre talking about twenty and above position. It‚Äôs scandalous. These are the things I expect should engage us as politicians. Our health systems, infrastructure, erosion, things that touch lives of people.

‚ÄúI‚Äôve intended not to talk about this but due to several calls I‚Äôve been received from people who insisted my views must be heard. I plead with my colleagues to be civil. Let‚Äôs face this campaign with credibility and character.

‚ÄúIt‚Äôll be most unfortunate to reason that the only way to distract people from real issues of insecurity is by these mundane things.

‚ÄúIssue of insecurity is the talk of the moment and there‚Äôs nothing you can do to distract the people from that. The reality is that the state is insecure and that something drastic has to be done.

‚ÄúOtherwise, we get ourselves consumed. No matter new information you bring, no matter the distractions, the fact remains people are being killed regularly.

Moghalu reiterated that addressing insecurity would be among the priority actions if elected governor of the state.

‚ÄúIn my 12 point agenda, insecurity is top priority. We can change the narratives by taking it from various perspectives, including through kinetic and non-kinetic.

‚ÄúWe‚Äôll tackle issues of unemployment which is producing a bank of criminals in the state,‚Äù he added

text:
MOGHALU SUSPENDS CAMPAIGN ACTIVITIES, VISITS ONITSHA MAIN MARKET, COMMITS TO OFFSETTING MEDICAL BILLS OF GUNSHOT VICTIMS

The Labour Party Governorship Candidate in Anambra State, Dr. George Moghalu, has suspended all his campaign activities for one week following Tuesday‚Äôs tragic shooting incident at the Onitsha Main Market, Emeka Offor Plaza axis by operatives of the Anambra State agency, Operation Clean and Healthy Anambra (OCHA) Brigade.

In a statement made available by his Special Assistant on Media, Mr. Johnson Okoye, Dr. Moghalu disclosed that he personally visited the Onitsha Main Market to commiserate with traders and families affected by the unfortunate incident. He described the killings as ‚Äúbarbaric, unacceptable, and a direct attack on the dignity of Ndi Anambra.‚Äù

Addressing the visibly shaken traders, Dr. Moghalu assured that a Labour Party-led government under his watch would never tolerate such reckless use of force against innocent citizens. He stressed that ‚Äúgovernment exists to protect lives, not to waste them.‚Äù

Deeply moved by the plight of those who sustained injuries, Dr. Moghalu pledged to offset the medical bills of all victims currently hospitalised as a result of the shooting. ‚ÄúAt a time like this, compassion, support, and solidarity are what the victims and their families need most. My heart goes out to them, and I will ensure that their medical expenses are fully taken care of,‚Äù he affirmed.

The governorship hopeful further vowed that the incident would be thoroughly investigated, insisting that all those responsible must be arrested and made to give account of their deeds.

Appealing for calm, he urged traders not to take laws into their own hands but to allow due process to prevail, assuring them that justice must be served without compromise.

Explaining his decision to suspend campaign activities, Dr. Moghalu noted that it was both a mark of respect for the victims and a demonstration of solidarity with Ndi Anambra in this moment of grief.

He called on Ndi Anambra to remain calm, resilient, and united, reminding them that ‚ÄúNovember 8 is our opportunity to enthrone a government that prioritises human lives, restores peace, and guarantees the safety of every citizen.‚Äù

ANAMBRA GA-ADI MMA OZO.

text:
PRESS STATEMENT

ONITSHA KILLINGS: NDI ANAMBRA MUST END THE REIGN OF BLOODSHED ON NOVEMBER 8 ‚Äî I HAVE DIRECTED FOR THE SUSPENSION OF MY CAMPAIGN FOR ONE WEEK

I received with deep shock and profound sadness the heartbreaking news of the killing of four innocent citizens, including a pregnant woman, at the Onitsha Main Market, Emeka Offor Plaza axis, allegedly by operatives of the government-backed OCHA Brigade.

From Udogachi to Aka ·ªåd·ªç, and now Ocha Bridge, Anambra has been witnessing a disturbing pattern of killings and violence. This is no longer governance; this is tragedy. For the past three years, our state has been drowning in negative headlines‚Äîkillings, bloodshed, kidnapping, and fear everywhere. Our people no longer feel safe going to the market, walking the streets, or even sitting in their own homes. We are now living on a battlefield, where citizens are gunned down not by criminals in the bush, but by those wearing government uniforms. This is not the Anambra of our dreams. How long shall we continue like this? How long shall the lives of our people be wasted by a government that has no compassion, empathy, or conscience? A government that cannot protect its citizens has no moral right to ask for their votes.

I condemn, in the strongest terms, this reckless use of force in collecting levies. Let it be known that under a Labour Party government, such barbarity will never be tolerated. No government agency will bear arms, aside from vigilantes. Security will not mean oppression. Government will not arm thugs in uniforms against its own people. We will value life, protect dignity, and restore peace.

November 8 is the moment of truth. This election is our opportunity to say, ‚ÄúEnough is enough.‚Äù Ndi Anambra must make a bold statement with their votes. This government may come again with money to buy votes, but remember‚Äîevery vote sold becomes tomorrow‚Äôs hardship, tears, and blood. We must not allow this cycle to continue.

As a mark of respect and solidarity with the grieving families and Ndi Anambra, I am suspending my community and market campaign tours for one week. This is not a time for politics; it is a time to mourn, reflect, and recommit ourselves to ending this bloodshed.

My heart goes out to the families of the victims. I share in their grief and pray for God‚Äôs comfort in this very painful time.

Dr. George Moghalu
Labour Party Governorship Candidate, Anambra State

text:
MOGHALU HAILS FRANCIS CARDINAL ARINZE ON 60TH EPISCOPAL ANNIVERSARY

The Labour Party Governorship candidate in the forthcoming November 8 governorship election in Anambra State, Dr. George Moghalu, has extended heartfelt felicitations to His Eminence, Francis Cardinal Arinze, on the 60th anniversary of his episcopal consecration, wishing him many more glorious years in the service of God and humanity.

Dr. Moghalu gave gratitude to God for the gift of Cardinal Arinze to the Universal Church and the Catholic Archdiocese of Onitsha, where Cardinal Arinze once served as Archbishop after being consecrated as Bishop on August 29, 1965 by Archbishop Charles Heerey, barely two years before the Nigerian civil war, and as such became the youngest Catholic Bishop in the world as at that time.

Reflecting on his personal encounters and prayerful solidarity with the His Eminence; Dr. Moghalu affirmed that Cardinal Arinze has remained true to the tenet of his episcopal motto, Regnum Christi Floreat (‚ÄúMay the Kingdom of Christ flourish‚Äù), as seen in his tireless service to the poor and needy, his profound scholarship, and his deeply enriching sermons.

As Cardinal Arinze, fondly known as Ochudo Uwa of Eziowelle marks this remarkable anniversary, Dr. Moghalu prayed for renewed grace, strength and vitality for the celebrant in his continued service to God and humanity.

Earlier today, I addressed the Association of Past President Generals of Anambra State (APAS) at their meeting in Amawbia, Awka South LGA, where I sought their partnership in the mission to rebuild our dear state. I reminded them that governance is not a tea party but a serious responsibility. Anambra, which once led the nation in education, has sadly lost that pride of place. Insecurity has worsened because our vigilantes are not properly trained, and without peace and stability, our economy cannot grow.

I shared with them my vision to reform and strengthen security, invest massively in agriculture, revive infrastructure, and empower our youths with opportunities. Where we are now is not where we are supposed to be, but with unity of purpose we can change the story. I assured them that I will not fail or disappoint Ndi Anambra, and I prayed with them for God‚Äôs guidance and strength as we work together for the peace, progress, and prosperity of our state.

Maka na Anambra ga-adi mma ozo!

text:
Umunnem Ndi Nnewi,

It is with deep joy and pride that I join you in celebrating this year‚Äôs Afiaolu Festival, our treasured heritage that binds us together as one family.

Afiaolu is more than a harvest festival; it is a sacred moment of thanksgiving to God, a reaffirmation of our identity, and a celebration of the unity that makes us Ndi Nnewi. text:
MOGHALU DISMISSES COURT ORDER AS JOKE, SAY OPPONENTS AFRAID OF HIS ACCEPTANCE

Labour Party Governorship Candidate in Anambra state, Dr George Moghalu has dismissed as joke and dead on arrival media report misinterpreting court order with claims of restraining him from parading himself as flagbearer of the party.

Social media was awash with reports claiming that Federal High Court sitting in Enugu had restrained Moghalu from parading himself as the governorship candidate of the Labour Party (LP) in the forthcoming November 8, 2025 poll.

Moghalu, in a press briefing on Tuesday said the misrepresented order was the handiwork of mischief makers who were afraid of his popularity and acceptability in the state.

He said he would not have reacted to the report if not for its sensitivity and the unnecessary tension it was generating across the state and beyond.

The LP flagbearer urged those who behind the report to leave him alone and rather meet him at the polling center on November 8 where the decision would be taken by the electorate.

He said, ‚ÄúOrdinarily, I wouldn‚Äôt have bothered myself talking about social media speculations as a matter of personal policy.

‚ÄúBut because of the sensitivity of the matter and the need to do certain level of clarification, it became necessary I speak to douse tension.

‚ÄúThat report is a joke of the highest order. It‚Äôs clear some persons threatened by my popularity and acceptability of my programmes for the people of the state.

‚ÄúThese people have been looking for ways to stop me. Actually, we‚Äôre expecting this one. For me, it actually came a bit late, but we‚Äôll still respond to it.

‚ÄúFor purposes of putting things in proper perspective, I came in and saw an order pasted in one of my properties in my town. As a law abiding citizen, I requested the order be brought so I can look at it.

‚ÄúThe order had seven prayers. Some of the prayers include that I should be restrained from parading myself as gubernatorial candidate of labor party in Anambra state.

‚ÄúThey also asked for a retraining order from INEC not to accept whatever has to do with my nomination as guber candidate.

‚ÄúThey also asked for substituted service. It‚Äôs important to state that the last paragraph of the court order states that all other prayers are hereby denied, while the applicants are directed to place all respondents on notice.

‚ÄúHowever all parties, including the applicants and the respondents must maintain status quo pending the hearing and determination of the substantive suit.

‚ÄúEverything they asked for except for substituted service were denied. And the status quo is that Moghalu won the primary and was declared by INEC as LP candidate.

‚ÄúLike I said, we know the source of this and those who procure them. They‚Äôre only justifying the pay. I wish them well because it‚Äôs an exercise in futility.

‚ÄúI repeat, let them leave me alone and wait for me in November 8 at the voting point. Instead, let them market themselves to Nd·ªã Anambra.

‚ÄúWhy are they so frightened? Their ultimate agenda is how they can remove my name from the ballot and contesting the election

text:
DR. GEORGE MOGHALU REMAINS THE AUTHENTIC LABOUR PARTY GOVERNORSHIP CANDIDATE IN ANAMBRA

Our attention has been drawn to false rumors circulating about Dr. George Moghalu‚Äôs candidacy for the Anambra State governorship. Ordinarily, such baseless claims would merit no response. However, in the interest of our supporters, party members, and well-meaning Ndi Anambra who could be misled, it has become necessary to set the record straight.

Let us state clearly and unequivocally: these rumors are entirely false. Dr. Moghalu‚Äôs candidacy is not in question. Legal actions in no way guarantee the outcome desired by those spreading misinformation. His emergence as the Labour Party‚Äôs governorship candidate followed all lawful and party procedures, was duly monitored by the Independent National Electoral Commission (INEC), and officially published. His legitimacy is indisputable.

We are fully aware of those behind these malicious rumors. Their objective is obvious: to distract our campaign and confuse Ndi Anambra, who rightly expect visionary and effective leadership. These are desperate tactics by politicians who, having lost their primaries, have migrated to other parties and now resort to cheap blackmail and propaganda. Ndi Anambra deserve to hear what these individuals can genuinely offer, not fabricated stories.

We therefore call on all Ndi Anambra and members of the public to disregard these malicious falsehoods. Dr. Moghalu‚Äôs candidacy remains firm, anchored in law, integrity, and the will of the people. Our campaign continues, unwavering, resolute, and fully focused on delivering a better Anambra for every citizen.

Signed:
Johnson Okoye
Special Assistant on Media to Dr. George Moghalu

text:
MOGHALU: UDOGACHI‚ÄôS ASSAULT ON CORPS MEMBER IS AN INSULT TO ANAMBRA, WILL NEVER BE TOLERATED UNDER MY WATCH

My heart is deeply troubled by the recent shameful incident at Oba, Idemili South, where operatives of Udo Gachi Homeland Security mercilessly assaulted a serving National Youth Service Corps (NYSC) member, Miss Jennifer Elohor. I watched the viral video like everyone else, and I could not believe the level of brutality, indignity and embarrassment meted out to a young lady who is only serving her fatherland.

Let me state it clearly: this action is irresponsible, it is barbaric, and it is an insult to Ndi Anambra. It has brought shame to our state, and no decent society can tolerate it.

This is not the first time Udo Gachi has acted with reckless impunity. They have killed our people, intimidated innocent citizens, and now they have gone as far as humiliating a corps member. Enough is enough. Any security outfit that cannot respect the dignity of human life has no business existing. That is why I am calling for Udo Gachi to be disbanded immediately. If they must exist, they should be properly trained and reoriented to understand that their duty is to protect lives, not destroy them.

No matter the offence a citizen may have committed, it is the duty of the police to investigate and prosecute, not a group of lawless enforcers. Udo Gachi has no legal or moral right to detain, flog, or humiliate anyone. Their excesses have gone beyond security; they have become a political tool in the hands of those who set them up.

We all saw what happened during the August 16 by-election. Instead of keeping the peace, they were cocking guns, beating voters, scattering ballot papers, and snatching boxes already stuffed with votes. Is that security? No. That is political thuggery, and it is an insult to Ndi Anambra‚Äôs intelligence.

Let me also remind our people that the Labour Party did not even participate in that by-election. INEC excluded our candidates. Yet, Governor Soludo went about claiming that he defeated Labour Party. Defeated who? A party that was not on the ballot? That was nothing but propaganda.

But come November 8, Ndi Anambra will speak with one voice. The real election will take place, and it will not be business as usual. It is not rocket science ‚Äî our people are tired, they are ready for change, and Labour Party is on ground.

I am demanding that the state government must produce Miss Elohor. She must be allowed to tell her story publicly, because she represents thousands of corps members serving in our state today. If this could happen to her in broad daylight, imagine what many others may be going through silently.

I also call on the Federal Government to act fast and rein in these so-called security operatives. If they fail, it will mean they are asking the people to defend themselves on November 8. As for me, I assure Ndi Anambra: under my watch, no such recklessness or barbarism will be tolerated.

Our people deserve security, not brutality. They deserve justice, not intimidation. They deserve dignity, not shame. That is the Anambra I am fighting to build.

‚Äì Chief Dr. George Moghalu
Labour Party Governorship Candidate, Anambra State

text:
For me, true charity begins at home. It is a principle deeply woven into my values and the way I live my life. 

I have never been one to broadcast the acts of service I am privileged to carry out for my people. From the abundance I‚Äôve been blessed with, I am constantly seeking meaningful ways to give back -not for recognition, but out of genuine commitment to uplift those around me. My greatest reward lies in the joy of those who benefit and the quiet approval of my conscience and my Creator.

Lately, I‚Äôve seen a few questions raised here about what I have done for my people. Normally, I choose not to respond, as I believe service should not be performed for applause. But for the sake of clarity- and only this once- I‚Äôll share a few examples.

Much of the work I‚Äôve done has remained undocumented, and intentionally so. However, some efforts have come to light simply due to the scale or nature of the impact. In 2020, in line with a personal pledge I made to provide homes for widows across the three senatorial zones of Anambra, I, through the Zim Uzo Foundation, built, fully furnished, and donated homes to two deserving widows. 

That act was not a campaign promise or a public relations effort- it was a quiet fulfillment of a commitment from the heart.
The Zim Uzo Foundation has since become a vital extension of my vision for community upliftment. Through it, we have awarded scholarships to outstanding students, supported human capital development initiatives, and offered economic aid to families in need. Our focus remains on sustainable empowerment-creating opportunities that transform lives.

I am a simple man, driven not by titles or positions, but by purpose. And as long as I draw breath, I will continue to serve- not because I must, but because I can. With or without any official role, I consider it my duty and honor to give back to the community that shaped me.

@ezeani_malik1 My brother, the time for passive calls for peace is over! However, we do not need to result to violence and blood shed. Instead, We must rise, stand firm, and resist the forces that seek to undermine our future. When a multitude gathers with unwavering resolve, evil cannot thrive. The power to change our destiny lies within each and every one of us.

Look at Abia, where a single brave woman, Prof. Nnenna, stood against the tide and allowed the will of the people to prevail. While not all of us may possess her extraordinary courage, we can all find the strength to do what is right.

Consider the recent bye-elections in Anambra. How can we decry the insecurity and incompetence of the current administration, yet willingly sell our votes for a mere 20k to 30k? While parts of our senatorial zone are being overtaken by insecurity and occupied by forces that threaten our very existence, we mortgage our future for short-term gain. Some parts of Ihiala is a bi go area yet the same people who have been abandoned for the last 4 years voted in the same administration in exchange of 30k. Who is to blame for this betrayal if not ourselves?

The truth is clear: change starts with us. We must refuse to be complicit in our own destruction. We must demand accountability, resist corruption, and fight for a better future for ourselves and generations to come. Let us rise together, united in purpose and unwavering in our commitment to building a brighter tomorrow!

text:
BY-ELECTION SHAME: ANAMBRA TREASURY TURNED INTO CASH BAZAAR

The Campaign Organization of Dr. George Moghalu and Hon. Mrs. Ifeoma Okaro notes with deep concern the boastful and misleading claims made by Governor Charles Chukwuma Soludo in Nanka after Saturday‚Äôs by-election, where he arrogantly declared that Labour Party and its governorship candidate were ‚Äúdefeated‚Äù in his polling unit.

Ordinarily, such empty chest-thumping should be ignored. But silence breeds distortion, and Ndi Anambra deserve the truth, plain and clear.

The truth is this: Labour Party had no candidate in the by-election. INEC had already made it clear that Labour Party could not participate in the August 16, 2025 by-elections anywhere in the country not for House of Assembly and not for Senate. How then could Governor Soludo boast of ‚Äúdefeating‚Äù Labour Party? Was any Labour Party candidate published by INEC? Did anyone see Labour Party campaign or posters anywhere? Clearly, Soludo‚Äôs so-called victory is nothing but a stage-managed comic act designed to deceive the public.

Yet, even without participating in the election, Ndi Anambra still demonstrated overwhelming affection for Labour Party. In several polling units, voters openly demanded to vote for Labour Party despite its exclusion. This speaks louder than Soludo‚Äôs propaganda. It shows Labour Party is not just a political party, but the very heartbeat of Ndi Anambra ‚Äîa people‚Äôs movement that cannot be silenced.

What played out on Saturday was not democracy but a bazaar of shame. The entire state watched as Anambra‚Äôs treasury was emptied to fund reckless vote buying, with reports of voters receiving up to ‚Ç¶30,000 each. This rain of cash only proves one thing: APGA and its government have nothing to offer except desperation and deceit.

This by-election has become an eye-opener. A governor who chants ‚ÄúSolution is Here‚Äù could not win without sharing money. If indeed Soludo has performed, why did he need to squander billions to ‚Äúprove‚Äù popularity? What credibility lies in a victory that was purchased, not earned?

Even worse, Governor Soludo now celebrates the ‚Äúdefeat‚Äù of a widow. Ndi Anambra must ask: what kind of leader spends billions just to humiliate a widow in an election? What kind of victory is this one without conscience?

And the bigger question: where is the security vote of Ndi Anambra? If billions can be released overnight to buy votes, why has Soludo failed to secure lives and property, fix our collapsing roads, revive hospitals, empower our youths with jobs, and restore hope in our communities? Why is there always money for vote buying but never money for governance?

Governor Soludo parades himself as a reformer and economist, but this election has exposed him as a reckless spender, a political trader, and a leader thriving on propaganda rather than performance. This is hypocrisy at its peak.

Let it be clear: Saturday‚Äôs by-election was no test of popularity. It was a one-sided drama because Labour Party did not participate. APGA should not deceive itself. November 8, 2025 will tell a different story  because Labour Party has a sellable and capable governorship candidate. Ndi Anambra will speak decisively at the ballot box.

Dr. George Moghalu and Hon. Mrs. Ifeoma Okaro remain unwavering in their commitment to provide Ndi Anambra with leadership anchored on service, security, accountability, and people-first governance as captured in our Recovery Agenda. Unlike APGA‚Äôs Soludo, our mission is not to buy votes but to build lives. Ndi Anambra deserve leaders who invest resources to secure their future, not squander them for fleeting bragging rights.

The countdown to November has begun. Labour Party is alive. Labour Party is strong. Labour Party is unstoppable. Ndi Anambra, the time to reclaim our state is now.

Signed:
 Arc. Okey Chukwuogo 
DG, Dr. George Moghalu & Hon. Mrs. Ifeoma Okaro Campaign Organization

text:
Ndi Anambra,

In moments like this, we must ask ourselves a crucial question:
Do we need more talk‚Äîor do we need real work?

In Igbo land, we say:
‚ÄúNwoke na ar·ª• ·ªçr·ª•, ·ªç b·ª•gh·ªã nwoke na-ekwu okwu.‚Äù
A true man is known by the work he does, not by the noise he makes.

We are tired‚Äîtired of empty promises and rehearsed speeches.
What we need now is leadership that delivers, not leadership that deceives.

What we need now is someone who will rescue our land from kidnappers and criminals.
Someone who will attract foreign investment, create jobs, and open doors of opportunity.
Someone who will end the Agbero menace and restore order in our markets and motor parks.
Someone who will reduce the suffering of our people, especially the over-taxed traders and small business owners.

We need a leader who will restore the people‚Äôs confidence in government‚Äî
A leader who listens, who serves, and who delivers.

Let us rally behind those whose track record speaks louder than their voices.
Let us support those who have built, not those who only boast.

The time has come to choose:
Action over speeches.
Results over rhetoric.
Service over showmanship.

text:
MOGHALU ANNOUNCES CAMPAIGN COUNCIL, NAMES OKOLI-AKIRIKA, OGENE, OROGBU, WIPER, UMENNAJIEGO, NGONADI, MBACHU AND OTHERS

AWKA - In a major political development ahead of the 2025 Anambra Governorship Election, the campaign organization of Dr. George Moghalu and his running mate, Mrs. Ifeoma Okaro, has officially unveiled the composition of its State Campaign Council.

The announcement, made on Monday by the Director General of the Campaign Organization, Arch. Okey Chukwuogo, features a formidable lineup of seasoned administrators, legal experts, technocrats, media professionals, grassroots mobilizers, youth and women leaders  all carefully selected to drive a people-centered and issue-based campaign across the state.

Among the prominent names in the council are Barr. CJ Okoli Akirika, who will lead the Administration Directorate; Hon. Afam Ogene, heading Media and Publicity; Prof. Oby Orogbu in Contact and Mobilization; Hon. Uchenna Okafor (Wiper) in Parks and Market; Prof. Patrick Nky Obi, heading Support Groups; Barr. Jude Umennajiego in Operations; and Dr. Obinna Ngonadi, also in Operations, while Hon. Nigeria Mbachu serves in Media and Publicity. 

The full breakdown of the Campaign Council is as follows:

OPERATION
Director: Hon. Fidelis Okafor
Deputy Director: Barr. Jude Umennajiego
Secretary: Dr. Obinna Ngonadi

ADMINISTRATION
Director: Barr. CJ Okoli Akirika
Deputy Director: Hon. Chijioke Nwajioha
Secretary: Arc. Josef Emefo

FINANCE
Director: Barr. Izuchukwu Unegbu
Deputy Director: Mrs. Uju Okoye
Secretary: Mrs. Helen Nweri

LEGAL
Director: B.I.E. Nwafor, SAN
Deputies: Barr. Emeka Nebo, Barr. Patrick Okafor
Secretary: Vincent Ottaokpakpu

MEDIA AND PUBLICITY
Director: Hon. Afam Ogene
Deputy Director: Engr. Theo Egbe
Secretary: Hon. Nigeria Mbachu

CONTACT AND MOBILIZATION
Director: Chief John Okigbo
Deputy Director: Prof. Oby Orogbu
Secretary: Arch. Mrs. Chinelo Ofoche

YOUTH AND STUDENT MOBILIZATION
Director: Hon. Izuchukwu Ejikeme (Wiper)
Deputy Director: Hon. Ezechukwu Ude
Secretary: Hon. Okey Nonyelu

WOMEN MOBILIZATION
Director: Barr. Oge Ekwezor
Deputy Director: Mrs. Amaka Ofojebe
Secretary: Mrs. Uju Egbuchiem

ELECTION MANAGEMENT
Director: Mr. OCN Okafor
Deputy Director: Mr. Onyeka Umeri
Secretary: Barr. Arinze Ikeabanife

SECURITY
Director: CP Mike Okoli (Rtd.)
Deputy Director: Comrade Chibuzo Ekwenye
Secretary: Chief Tony Adinweruka

PROTOCOL
Director: Mr. Tony Mmadubuko
Deputy Director: Mr. Curtis Okeke

text:
RE: GOVERNOR SOLUDO'S UTTERANCES AT EKWULOBIA, ANAMBRA DESERVES ACCOUNTABILITY NOT MOCKERY

The attention of the Dr. George Moghalu Campaign Organization has been drawn to the unfortunate and reckless remarks made by Governor Chukwuma Soludo during a political rally at Ekwulobia. In a speech filled with mockery and condescension, Governor Soludo referred to citizens of our state as ‚Äústreet urchins‚Äù and went on to declare that any governorship candidate who pledges to serve a single term ‚Äúneeds psychiatric examination.‚Äù

This kind of language is unbecoming of the high office he occupies. Rather than speak to the real challenges facing Ndi Anambra, Governor Soludo has chosen to insult the sensibilities of the electorate in an apparent show of desperation.

For clarity, the Nigerian Constitution allows an elected official to serve one term, not a mandatory two. A second term is earned through performance, not demanded as a birthright. Leadership is a privilege to serve, not an entitlement. Nelson Mandela is still regarded as the father of democracy in Africa. Guess what Mr. Soludo, he served only one term.

Three years into his administration, Governor Soludo has yet to account for the lofty promises he made to Ndi Anambra. The people are asking: Where is the ‚ÄúAfrica Dubai Taiwan‚Äù transformation he promised? Let him show us one foreign investment he has attracted to Anambra. Why has insecurity escalated under his watch, with a disturbing rise in killings and kidnappings even in the state capital? What are his visible and verifiable achievements in education, health, job creation, and infrastructure?

These are the questions Ndi Anambra are asking not because of political rivalry, but because their lives and livelihoods are at stake.

For someone who once claimed he is not contesting with anyone, Governor Soludo‚Äôs outburst reeks of panic. If truly he isn‚Äôt worried, why the insults? Why the mockery? His words betray fear, fear of a people rising, fear of accountability, and fear of a credible alternative in Dr. George Moghalu.

Governor Soludo is becoming increasingly boastful and arrogant, forgetting that power belongs to God and to the people. Let him remember it is God who raises up and brings down kings. His tone no longer reflects service, but entitlement. When a leader begins to mock the very people he swore to serve, it is a clear sign he has lost touch with reality, and the people will remind him on November 8 that no one holds Anambra hostage.

It is unfortunate that instead of offering answers, the Governor has chosen to drag the conversation to the gutters with insults. It is particularly disheartening that a sitting Governor would resort to such unguarded rhetoric, thereby dishonoring the legacy of Anambra‚Äôs founding icons, Dim Chukwuemeka Odumegwu Ojukwu, Prof. Chinua Achebe, Dr. Nnamdi Azikiwe, Dr. Alex Ekwueme, and Rt. Hon. Nwafor Orizu, men who embodied dignity, courage, and visionary leadership. They would be turning in their graves at the mockery being made of the governorship seat today.

This is a betrayal of the values of leadership and a disservice to the proud political heritage of our people.

In sharp contrast, Dr. George Moghalu represents the kind of leadership Ndi Anambra need at this critical time. He has pledged to serve only one term, not out of weakness, but out of conviction to respect zoning, restore balance, and deliver results. With his proven record in both public and private service, he believes that four years is enough for a focused and capable governor to turn things around.
As we move toward the November 8 election, the people must choose between careless arrogance and thoughtful leadership, between broken promises and a credible plan for recovery.

Dr. George Moghalu remains committed to engaging the people with respect, humility, and a clear vision. As a focused gentleman, he will not trade insults but will continue to speak directly to the needs and hopes of Ndi Anambra.

üíº‚ÄØPublic Servant | Visionary Leader | Advocate for Good Governance

text:
Umunnem Ndi Anambra,

As we step into the month of August, I extend my warmest wishes to you and your loved ones. May this new month bring peace, renewed strength, and steady progress in all your pursuits.

August, often associated with hope and harvest, reminds us that better days are possible when we stand together. I pray your efforts yield good results and your homes remain safe and joyful, as we continue the journey toward a better Anambra.

However, it is impossible to ignore the harsh reality before us. The alarming rise in insecurity across our state is deeply disturbing. From kidnappings and targeted killings to armed robberies and cult violence, fear now grips our communities. Even in Awka, our state capital, nowhere feels safe. This is not the Anambra we were promised.

I am greatly troubled by this growing wave of violence. The pain, trauma, and economic disruption it causes are unacceptable. I will not stay silent, and I assure you, under my leadership, this trend will not be allowed to continue.

If given the mandate to serve, I will place security at the center of my agenda. We will adopt proactive, community-based strategies including enhanced surveillance, effective policing, and support for local vigilante groups through proper training, funding, and accountability. We will restore public trust and engage our youths meaningfully.

Let this August mark a turning point where fear begins to give way to hope, and violence is replaced with peace. Together, we can build a safe, just, and prosperous Anambra where every life is valued and no child grows up seeing violence as normal.

God bless you.
God bless Anambra State.

Dr. George Moghalu
Labour Party Governorship Candidate
Anambra State.
